Context Cortex 2.0: The Realistic, Executable Plan The Pivot: From Infrastructure to Implementation Original Problem: Context Cortex 1.0 tried to be infrastructure (API layer). Infrastructure sales are slow, technical, and require enterprise credibility you don't have yet. New Approach: Be the done-for-you AI implementation service that uses context intelligence as your secret weapon. Business Name: Cortex Implementations One-Sentence Pitch: "We implement AI agents that actually know your business—guaranteed working in 2 weeks or your money back—because we've solved the context problem everyone else ignores." Why This Version Works Better 1. Faster Sales Cycle Old: "Buy our API and integrate it yourself" (3-6 month sales cycle) New: "We'll build you a working AI customer support agent in 2 weeks for €3k" (1-2 week sales cycle) 2. Immediate Cash Flow Old: Monthly subscriptions that take months to build up New: €3k-€5k upfront implementation fees + €500/month maintenance 3. Prove Value First Old: They pay before seeing results New: They see a working solution in week 1, pay when satisfied 4. Lower Technical Barrier Old: Clients need technical teams to integrate your API New: You do everything, they just use itThe Specific Offer (Ultra-Focused) Target: B2B SaaS Companies with Zendesk (or similar) + 100+ support tickets/month What You Build For Them: "The Context-Aware Support Agent" A custom AI agent that: 1. Has read and understood their entire knowledge base, previous tickets, and product documentation 2. Can answer 60-70% of tier-1 support questions instantly 3. Routes complex issues to humans with full context 4. Gets smarter every week by learning from human responses Pricing Structure: Implementation: €3,500 (one-time, paid 50% upfront, 50% on delivery) Monthly Maintenance: €650/month (covers API costs, monitoring, weekly improvements) Money-Back Guarantee: If it doesn't handle 50+ tickets in the first month, full refund The €0-€10k Roadmap (Realistic Timeline) Month 1:

Title: "Enhanced Energy Expenditure and Activity Type Prediction Through Multi-Sensor Data Integration and Advanced Neural Network Modeling" Abstract: The paper introduces a novel approach to Physical Activity Monitoring (PAM) by integrating multi-sensor data from wearables and environmental factors with advanced deep learning models. This study aims to overcome the limitations of traditional machine learning models in classifying similar physical activities and estimating energy expenditure, by leveraging big data and neural network modeling, particularly focusing on Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks. Introduction: Why? Existing PAM systems show limitations in distinguishing activities with similar movement patterns and accurately estimating energy expenditure. This research aims to address these challenges by applying an integrated approach that combines data from multiple sources and utilizes the capabilities of advanced neural networks. Research and Technical Objectives: Develop a deep learning model that integrates multi-sensor wearable data and environmental factors to improve the accuracy of physical activity classification. Compare the performance of the proposed model against traditional machine learning models in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency. Assess the impact of including environmental data on the prediction accuracy of different physical activities and energy expenditures. Evaluate the real-time processing capabilities of the proposed model for potential deployment in wearable devices. Investigate the model's adaptability and personalization potential across different user demographics. Correct Sampling Strategy: The study will recruit a diverse population exceeding the initial 9 subjects to ensure variety in age, health status, and physical activity patterns. A stratified sampling method will be used to ensure representativeness across different groups, enhancing the model's generalization capability. Domain and Problem Area of Focus: The research focuses on the domain of health and fitness, specifically improving the accuracy and reliability of Physical Activity Monitoring systems through deep learning and big data integration. Adding Value to the Area of Research Already Done:

different groups, enhancing the model's generalization capability. Domain and Problem Area of Focus: The research focuses on the domain of health and fitness, specifically improving the accuracy and reliability of Physical Activity Monitoring systems through deep learning and big data integration. Adding Value to the Area of Research Already Done: This study intends to extend the existing body of PAM research by introducing an advanced model that can handle complex data patterns and provide more precise activity recognition and energy expenditure estimates. By incorporating environmental factors, the research adds a new dimension to activity monitoring, providing insights into how external conditions affect physical activities. Understanding & Managing Bias: To mitigate bias, the study will use diverse datasets and validate the model across different populations. Techniques like cross-validation, regularization, and ensemble methods will be employed to reduce overfitting and ensure the model's robustness and fairness. Researching Vulnerable Groups: The study will include vulnerable groups such as the elderly or individuals with chronic conditions to ensure the model's effectiveness and adaptability across different health statuses. Ethics in Data Analytics: The research will adhere to ethical standards by obtaining informed consent from all participants, anonymizing personal data, and ensuring the privacy and security of collected data. The study will also transparently address any potential ethical issues arising from data collection, analysis, and model deployment. Methodology: Detailed steps covering data collection, preprocessing, model development, and evaluation, following the guidelines and objectives outlined. Results and Discussion: Analysis of the model's performance compared to existing solutions, discussion of the findings, and their implications for PAM systems. Conclusion and Future Work: Summarize the contributions of the research and propose directions for future studies, particularly focusing on further personalization and adaptation of the model to different environmental contexts and user needs. By following this structure, the research aims

discussion of the findings, and their implications for PAM systems. Conclusion and Future Work: Summarize the contributions of the research and propose directions for future studies, particularly focusing on further personalization and adaptation of the model to different environmental contexts and user needs. By following this structure, the research aims to provide a significant contribution to the field of Physical Activity Monitoring, addressing existing gaps and introducing innovative solutions through the use of advanced neural network architectures and big data analytics.

Rapid elasticity Capabilities can be elastically provisioned and released, in some cases automatically, to scale rapidly outward and inward commensurate with demand. To the consumer, the capabilities available for provisioning often appear to be unlimited and can be appropriated in any quantity at any time. 5. It may be owned, managed, and operated by the organization, a third party, or some combination of them, and it may exist on or off premises. Community cloud The cloud infrastructure is provisioned for exclusive use by a specific community of consumers from organizations that have shared concerns (e.g., mission, security requirements, policy, and 10/10 compliance considerations). ● But they are transparent ● Represents a natural evolution of cloud services abstraction 3 Serverless Computing [2] ● Emphasis on building (higher-level blocks) rather than managing (eliminating cloud stack complexity) ● Greater infrastructure utilisation and multi-tenancy density ● Synonyms and conflations: ○ Backend-as-a-service ○ Functions-as-a-service 4 Serverless Computing in Comparison Conventional service (in the cloud) Serverless service Database instance (e.g. RDS) Key-value store (e.g. AWS DynamoDB) Block storage (mounted on virtual instance) API-addressed bucket storage (e.g. AWS S3) Reverse Proxy or Load Balancer (e.g. NGINX) Configurable Gateway (e.g. AWS API Gateway) Virtual Machine or Container Instance Funcion-as-a-service (e.g. AWS Lambda, Cloudflare workers) 5 Bespoke, standalone authentication node Auth-as-service identity management (e.g. Auth0) Potential Benefits ● Lower relative operational cost ● Lower relative development cost ● Automatic scaling (in and out) ● Lower operational complexity ● Faster deployment ○ Fine-grained usage charges ○ Focus effort only on direct value add (code and data) ○ Fine-grained elastic resizing proportional to usage ○ Less to

Potential Benefits ● Lower relative operational cost ● Lower relative development cost ● Automatic scaling (in and out) ● Lower operational complexity ● Faster deployment ○ Fine-grained usage charges ○ Focus effort only on direct value add (code and data) ○ Fine-grained elastic resizing proportional to usage ○ Less to manage 6 ○ Less to deploy and update in refresh cycles Functions-as-a-Service ● On-demand execution of user-defined code fragments in response to some specified event(s) ○ HTTP API Request ○ File update on bucket storage ○ Message queue event or a timer event ● Code executes in isolated, virtual environment to completion and then unloads ● Optional temporal caching (for efficient re-execution) 7 ● Access to other cloud services (e.g. databases) ● Zero-infrastructure management for users, infinitely scalable 8 Deployment Size (FaaS) ● Although called functions-as-a-service, the real distinction is the size and content of the deployed asset ● In VMs, we deploy whole application stacks including OS; with containers we just deploy the runtime application file system image ● In FaaS, we just deploy code; Either source code to be interpreted or byte code or machine code to be executed ● FaaS represents the smallest logical composable execution unit; promotes a componentization approach to development; think microservice architectures ● This also make FaaS apps fast to deploy and update 10 CASE STUDY: AWS API Gateway, AWS Lambda ● URL endpoints mapped to AWS Lambda functions (entry points to event handling logic) ○ Variety of languages supported ○ Dozens of 3rd-party helper frameworks emerging ● Typically, performs some database or file object access ● Theoretically, each event execution creates independent AWS Lambda execution context 11 ● Execution contexts isolated and virtualised from each other ○ Speculation is that these are containerised ○ Although temporal caching may be in effect CASE

THE SLEREXE COMPANY LIMITED SAPORS LANE - BOOLE - DORSET - BH 25 8ER TELEPHONE BOOLE (945 13) 51617 - TELEX 123456 Our Ref. 350/PJC/EAC 18th January, 1972. Dr. P.N. Cundall, Mining Surveys Ltd., Holroyd Road, Reading, Berks. Dear Pete, Permit me to introduce you to the facility of facsimile transmission. In facsimile a photocell is caused to perform a raster scan over the subject copy. The variations of print density on the document cause the photocell to generate an analogous electrical video signal. This signal is used to modulate a carrier, which is transmitted to a remote destination over a radio or cable communications link. At the remote terminal, demodulation reconstructs the video signal, which is used to modulate the density of print produced by a printing device. This device is scanning in a raster scan synchronised with that at the transmitting terminal. As a result, a facsimile copy of the subject document is produced. Probably you have uses for this facility in your organisation. Yours sincerely, ThA. P.J.
